Abstract: Malaysia announces that it has extended by six months a deadline for resolving impasse on $3.8 billion worth of Malaysian stocks frozen on Singapore exchange; Malaysia had earlier threatened to unilaterally transfer all shares to Ministry of Finance if issue was not resolved; problem began when Malaysia imposed capital controls in September 1998, and suspended trade of Malaysian shares off shore; Malaysian and Singapore market authorities have clashed ever since over how to return shares to Malaysian marketplace; most of investors in shares are Singaporeans (M)
Snippet: Malaysia announces that it has extended by six months a deadline for resolving impasse on $3.8 billion worth of Malaysian stocks frozen on Singapore exchange; Malaysia had earlier threatened to unilaterally transfer all shares to Ministry of Finan...
LeadParagraph: Malaysia announced today that it had extended by six months a deadline for resolving an impasse on $3.8 billion worth of Malaysian stocks frozen on a Singapore exchange.

Headline.Main: Malaysia Extends Deadline in Singapore Exchange Dispute
Headline.PrintHeadline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; Malaysia Extends Deadline in Singapore Exchange Dispute
